it seems like you're going through a lot right now. i'm glad you went to the er and had a ct scan, and it's good that you saw your regular doctor as well. although it's understandable that you're feeling anxious about the situation. 

for now, it's crucial to focus on the fact that your doctors have been vigilant with testing and scanning, and they didn't find anything immediately dangerous. the small amount of blood in your urine may or may not be related to your symptoms, but it's good that they're looking into it further with the blood tests. 

in the meantime, if your pain gets much worse, especially if it becomes severe, or if you develop a fever or symptoms like vomiting or severe nausea, it would be appropriate to seek further immediate medical attention, whether that be via urgent care or the emergency room. 

on the psychological aspect, it's critical to work on managing your anxiety in this situation. i know that is easier said than done, but using the techniques you are familiar with to manage your anxiety can help. it's also important to remind yourself regularly that you are under medical care and doing everything you can to figure this out. 

please know that while it feels scary, it's extremely unlikely that this situation would escalate to a point of immediate life-threatening danger. many conditions that could potentially cause your symptoms are treatable. i highly recommend following up with your regular doctor to discuss your ongoing concerns.

i'm sorry to hear you're feeling so scared and unwell. the abdominal pain you're experiencing, combined with lower back pain and blood in your urine, could indeed be symptoms of a urinary tract infection (uti). the pain often occurs on one side and can radiate to the back. a uti is typically not a life-threatening condition, but if left untreated it could potentially lead to a kidney infection which is more serious.

blood in the urine isn't always visible to the naked eye and can sometimes only be detected through lab tests. it looks like your doctors are doing the right tests to figure out what's going on.

if the pain becomes worse or if you develop fever, vomiting, or become unable to urinate, seek immediate medical attention. in the meantime, keep yourself hydrated and try to minimize stress as much as possible. being anxious can sometimes make pain seem worse than it is.

there are conditions like kidney stones that can cause blood in urine and pain in the back and abdomen, but your doctor would be best at deciding whether this is something you should get tested for. also, be mindful that abdominal pain can be made worse by anxiety and stress, so try to keep this in mind as you wait for your test results. your ct scan was clear, which is good news and excludes many serious causes. 

i do understand your concerns and it's completely okay to be anxious. but remember, it's very unlikely you have a life-threatening condition based on the symptoms you mentioned. 

however, always remember that this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may or may not apply to your situation. always consult with your personal doctor or a healthcare professional for accurate information.

i understand your worries and anxiety, but do know that although finding the cause of an unexplained abdominal pain can be frustrating, it is unlikely that you will die before monday from an undiagnosed acute condition. the absence of fever and normal ct scan are generally reassuring signs. if the pain noticeably increases in intensity, becomes unbearable, or you notice any new worrying symptom such as severe nausea and vomiting, high fever or palpitations, do not hesitate to return to the emergency department. it is equally important that you get enough rest, stay hydrated, and nourish your body properly during this time. you may want to consider over-the-counter pain relief (if this is not contraindicated for you) to help manage discomfort. keep in mind that this advice is no replacement for a medical assessment by a trained professional. if you're worried about any change in your condition, do not hesitate to seek further medical help. the blood results on monday will hopefully provide more insight into the cause of your symptoms.

as for the blood in urine, it's not uncommon for urine to contain small amounts of blood that aren't visible to the eye. it could be a sign of a urinary tract infection, but it could also result from a kidney stone, renal disease, or even just strenuous exercise. the blood tests will give more information on what might be causing this. 

meanwhile, try to control your anxiety by practicing deep breathing, meditation, yoga or other techniques if you're comfortable with them, as high stress levels can worsen gastrointestinal symptoms.

i'm a doctor so i can understand your worries. if a ct scan was done in er which showed normal appendix, then there is little chance that your pain could be from appendicitis. the fact that your urine test showed blood is an important clue and could point towards a urinary tract infection or a kidney stone, both of which can cause the type of symptoms you are experiencing with pain in the lower abdomen and back. these issues can certainly be painful but are not typically life-threatening. while it's better to be checked thoroughly than ignore symptoms, in your case, given the tests you've had, i would suggest that you try not to worry too much about a serious condition being missed. please try to stay well-hydrated with water, and keep an eye out for any new symptoms. seek medical attention if your pain becomes severe or if you develop high fever or vomiting. it's also best to reach out to your primary care doctor about your ongoing concerns and new symptoms. they may provide more suitable pain relief and further evaluation/treatment if needed.

i'm really sorry to hear that you've been feeling unwell, but i want to assure you that it's important to keep communication open with your healthcare professionals who have more understanding about your condition and the examinations that you have gone through. it's also crucial to understand that the symptom of persistent abdominal pain can be due to a range of conditions, not all of which are serious or life threatening. 

the presence of microscopic hematuria (blood in the urine that isn't visible to the naked eye) could possibly suggest a urinary tract infection, stones, or other irritation in the urinary system, especially when accompanied by abdominal and back pain. 

it's also worth mentioning that conditions like irritable bowel syndrome, constipation, or gases can also cause similar symptoms. 

please don't panic, have adequate rest and keep yourself hydrated. you might consider non-prescription pain relief like acetaminophen/paracetamol for the time being, but consult your pharmacist or healthcare provider first to ensure it's safe with your underlying conditions and medications. remember, while awaiting your lab results, if your pain significantly worsens, you develop a fever, or new symptoms arise, you should seek immediate medical attention.

i'm sorry to hear that you're not feeling well and that you're scared. the symptoms you're experiencing can be caused by several different things; it's not unusual for things not to be immediately clear. i know that can be frustrating. a urinary tract infection (uti) could indeed cause the symptoms you're describing, including abdominal pain and a few red blood cells in your urine that aren't visible to the naked eye. the lower back pain could also be related to the uti, as the kidneys (located in the lower back) can be affected. additionally, constipation can also cause lower abdominal pain, especially if your bowel movements have been less frequent or smaller than your normal.

utis and constipation are both very common and are highly treatable. it's very unlikely to be a life-threatening condition. however, i understand that waiting can be hard, especially when you're in discomfort and feeling anxious.

for the abdominal pain, a gentle heat pack might help. make sure it's not too hot, and always use something like a towel between the pack and your skin. over-the-counter medication, like tylenol (provided it's safe for you and you've used it before) can sometimes be helpful for pain as well. 

for the constipation, drinking lots of water and eating foods high in fiber can help promote a bowel movement. gentle exercise can stimulate your gut as well.

you are doing the right things by going to the er and following up with your doctor. keep monitoring your symptoms, if you notice any change or if your symptoms significantly worsen, don't hesitate to seek medical attention again. the information provided here is no substitute for your doctor's advice.
